The animation of a refrigerator at work is completely reversed and incorrect: after the liquid is turned into a gas it is compressed at which point it flows to the condenser to shed the heat extracted in the fridge(and the heat generated by being compressed) and return to a liquid. This liquid is then sent through an orifice or long, thin capillary tube so that it pressure is reduced hence it's temperature lowered. This liquid then goes to the evaporator inside the fridge where it absorbs heat from the interior and boils into a gas before returning to the compressor. The animation shows the compressor as a "decompressor" or expansion device(orifice, capillary tube) and that is opposite of it's true function as the whole thing is reversed.

Thanks! The production value is great. However:  At 05:00 you say that there is an isothermal process where heat is slowly added, but the animation shows lots of heat (Q_H) escaping. What gives?  At 05:04 You say that the isothermal expansion is 1/2 AB. Shouldn't it be the entire path AB?   At 05:15 you say "the temperature drops whilst the heat stays constant, which also makes the volume expand". Well this is misleading: a temperature drop would cause an isolated system volume to contract. However in a Carnot engine, the system is doing work on the atmosphere, converting internal energy into work, and dropping the temperature. It's best to say that the expansion work drops the temperature, not that a colder temperature causes an expansion.  Also, when you keep saying "the heat stays constant", shouldn't you be saying "there is no heat flow" or something equivalent?  At 05:40 you say "the heat doesn't change" but perhaps you should be saying that there is no heat flow, or the system is thermally insulated, or something else equivalent.  The way you explain it sounds as if heat is a state property, when it's not.

What do you mean by a "hydraulic engine"?  A big problem in communicating physics and other sciences is that the English language, and others as well, is not restricted to scientific meanings.  An example is "potential" which physicists and chemists use to mean a difference in available energy, but you and I might use to describe the likelihood that our granddaughter will grow up to be Prime Minister, "She has great potential".
LOL! What material is the jar and lid made out of? Also, you say "I can't just wait for the water to evaporate", does that mean the seal lets out water vapour? Then you could heat the water inside.

Occam's razor isn't really about any blade. It's about the solution to the problem being the obvious one.  Taking a hammer to the jar isn't damaging it. It is still a jar. All you done is randomized it. No part of the jar isn't a jar anymore. The lid is still holding the lip of the jar, no holes where punched or drilled. Hmmm?  I'm not sure what point your teacher is trying to make.  It certainly does not seem like part of the standard physics curriculum, in the sense of physical phenomena or theory.  He could be trying to get you to think through all of the things you know about the system.  That is a basic skill in science (and the rest of life), but it is not always an explicit part of curricula.  Being presented with a really difficult, perhaps even impossible, problem is one way to motivate a thorough examination of what you know about the system  Please post his answer here.
I too wish to know the answer to your teacher's test.

It is also useful to realize that there are problems and devices that are, according to our best understanding, impossible.  There are any number of perpetual motion machines, massless rocket drives, etc that are impossible based on known science.  When someone presents an idea that seems impossible based on our best knowledge, the bar for proof becomes higher.  The maxim is, "Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence".   The practical rationale for this is that science, particularly physics, is no longer a newborn.  Many fields of science are quite mature, with well developed and well supported ideas.  If something is claimed that contradicts what is well established, we do not just throw out what is well established on a whim.

Where would electric engines stand? They start off with ambient heat, max torque at 0rpms, output heat is significantly lower than a steam or an IC engine, practically all are reversible.  (Edited to fix auto correct errors)

You can't design a very good engine without understanding the theory.  Early steam engines were less than 1% efficient and very dangerous.  If you just want to build a small engine for fun, it would be best to just copy an existing design, since all the factors will have been worked out by someone else.  It would take a whole series just to go over the different engine cycles: rankine (steam), stirling, diesel (diesel), otto (gasoline cars), brayton (jet engine), Lenoir (ramjet), and more.  The easiest would probably be a small stirling cycle with air (could be made small and fairly safely).  There are stirling engine designs out there you can look up.  But to design something from scratch to be useful is very, very difficult.

An electric motor is not a heat engine so this course segment does not cover how the motor converts potential energy into work.

Electric engines convert electromagnetic energy into kinetic energy. It's an entirely different process.  In principle, an electric engine is the same as a generator, but used in reverse. If you spin it, it produces an alternating current. If you give it some AC, it will try to spin fast enough to match the frequency of the current.

I don't think this series has really explained entropy well enough for a T-s diagram to be helpful to anyone hearing about thermodynamics for the first time.  As far as reversibility goes, isothermal and adiabatic processes are required, du to the definition of reversibility.   Any heat transfer from a high temperature to a lower one produces entropy. A reversible process produces no entropy. If there is no temperature difference during the heat exchange, no entropy is produced, making isothermal processes the only reversible kind of process that allows for heat exchange, while adiabatic processes pass for reversible by not having any heat exchange that can produce entropy.

I don't think this series has really explained entropy well enough for a T-s diagram to be helpful to anyone hearing about thermodynamics for the first time.  As far as reversibility goes, isothermal and adiabatic processes are required, du to the definition of reversibility.   Any heat transfer from a high temperature to a lower one produces entropy. A reversible process produces no entropy. If there is no temperature difference during the heat exchange, no entropy is produced, making isothermal processes the only reversible kind of process that allows for heat exchange, while adiabatic processes pass for reversible by not having any heat exchange that can produce entropy.

You have stated a contradiction " A reversible process produces no entropy. "; the isothermal process of carnot engine DO produce entropy, you can easly check the T-s diagram or think in terms of dQ = TdS; for heat to be transferred you need to augment the entropy content.
An isentropic (no entropy change) process is adiabatic (no heat transfer) by definition.

Abraham Vivas Isothermal heat exchange leads to entropy being transferred, but no entropy is produced, in the ideal case.  dQ = TdS only deals with entropy transfer in internally reversible processes. I'm not saying the entropy doesn't change in a reversible process, only that no new entropy is produced. Any entropy increase in a Carnot process is brought in with the added heat, and transferred back out again, when the system gets rid of heat.

okey, but it doesnt explain the reason of the choose if isothermal process, as you say, the equality dQ = TdS deals with reversible processes, with that equation i can describe other processes like isobaric processes... like in a ideal Bryton Cycle... That was my point, that its confusing the explanation of the choose of isothermal process and why its favor the reversibility... as she explains, she says that for a process to be reversible must not be temperature gradients within the woking fluid... that can be achieved in a isobaric process within a piston where the heat trasfer is slow enough to let the process to be quasi-static... So you can have any process to be reversible, not just isothermal ones.

Abraham Vivas That's a great point. All of the ideal thermodynamic processes are assumed to be reversible, as you say. But that's just down to the definition, since reversibility requires that no entropy is produced. I didn't think about that, and gave you a bad example. I'm sorry.  If we move away from the ideal, however, isothermal and adiabatic processes are the closest thing we have to reversible processes, because they either don't change the temperature, or they don't exchange heat. you can even adjust the heat exchange in an isothermal process to match the entropy production, but that just means you put less heat into the system, while removing the same amount of heat you did before, giving you less work. In reality, friction and other factors will make sure that no process is truly reversible.   If you want the mathematical reason why the carnot cycle is considered the ideal, it can be made fairly clear using as T-s diagram.  All cycles have a state with maximum temperature, and maximum entropy. Same goes for their minimums. Draw vertical lines to mark out the maximum and minimum entropy levels. Then draw horizontal lines to mark the maximum and minimum temperature values. These lines should now intersect to form a rectangle, that shows the restrictions of the system. They also represent the Carnot cycle of the system. Trying to find a more efficient cycle for that system would be equivalent to trying to draw a loop within the rectangle, that enclosed a bigger area than the rectangle.  The horizontal lines of the rectangle make up isothermal processes, while the vertical ones are isentropic (aka ideal adiabatic).

After watching the full video, my money is still on Maxwell's Demon which has been created both mechanically and chemically.

No.  A Carnot engine has nothing, directly, to do with Maxwell's demon.  It is also important to point to point out that, as of Sept 22, 2016, Maxwell's demon remains a totally imaginary device.  It was and is a thought experiment.  Even as a thought experiment, it is generally considered that it could not violate the second law of thermodynamics, though the theoretical thinking involved is quite abstract.  There have been practical devices built that have some characteristics of a Maxwell's demon, but none of these, either in theory or practice, violate the second law.

I think I should clarify what I mean by a "practical" device that has some characteristics of a Maxwell's demon.  By practical, I mean a real device working with real atoms and molecules, not merely a theoretical construct.  However, these devices are not practical in a larger sense.  They are laboratory research devices.  They allow research into interesting physics and chemistry.  They will not power your lawnmower.
